name: Delete SOP
description: The Delete SOP deletes input geometry as selected by a group specification or a geometry selection by using either of the three selection options: by entity number, by a bounding volume, and by entity (primitive/point) normals. You can choose to delete the selected or the non-selected geometry.
summary: The Delete SOP deletes input geometry as selected by a group specification or a geometry selection by using either of the three selection options: by entity number, by a bounding volume, and by entity

parameters.name: Group
parameters.label: Group
parameters.description:
From Derivative
		
		
		
		
		Jump to navigation
		Jump to search
		
The Delete  deletes input geometry as selected by a group specification or a geometry selection by using either of the three selection options: by entity number, by a bounding volume, and by entity (primitive/point) normals. You can choose to delete the selected or the non-selected geometry.
deleteSOP_Class

Contents
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 





  group - The name of the group to be created. The default name is set to match the name of the .


			
  negate -  - Choose to Delete the Selected Geometry or Delete the Non-Selected .

 dele - keep -
			
  entity -  - Choose to delete primitives or points.

 primitive - point -
			
  geotype -  - Select the geometry type group. The selection will only pertain to the geometry type specified. e.g. If you only wanted to group polygons.

 all - All geometry will be selected. bezierc - bezier - circle - mesh - meta - nurbc - nurb - part - poly - sphere - tube - tristrip - trifan -



Allows selection of grouping of entities by number. When checked, the options relative to this selection option are displayed.

  usenumber - When the Enable button is checked under the Number button, the selection options become active and can be used to select entities. The fields available are listed below.


		
  groupop -  - When the Number Enable button is checked, this option groups entities based on a defined Pattern or by a Range.

 pattern - Select a pattern in the Pattern field below. range - Select a Range using the Start/End and Select_of_ fields below. filter - Select a range using the Filter  field below.
		
  pattern - Activated when Operation is set to Group by Pattern. In this field, enter the range of primitives to select. The required syntax is "S.P", where S is the index of the parent surface, and P the profile index on that surface. You can mix primitives with profiles in the list. A mixed group is automatically ordered.	
For example;0.4 2 4 2.5 3.7 selects three profiles and two primitives0-100:2 selects every other number from 0 to 1000-10:2,3 selects every two of three0.0-6 selects six profiles on primitive 00.* selects all profiles on primitive 0!4 selects every primitive or point except the fourth9-0 selects first ten (in reverse if ordered flag is on)!0.* selects all profiles except those on primitive 0* selects all primitives or points, and no profiles			
See  in the [Scripting Guide]


		
  range -  - Activated when Operation is set to Group by Range. Select the start and end of the primitive/point number selection.

rangestart -rangeend -
		
  select -  - Activated when Operation is set to Group by Range. Select every nth occurrence of every mth entity in the above Start/End range.	
For example; entering 1 and 2 selects 1 out of every 2 entities


select1 -select2 -
		
  filter - The Filter  provided is evaluated for every point/primitive. Wherever it is true, the entity is added to the selection.





This option is used for selecting entities based on bounding volumes: Bounding Box, or Bounding Sphere. When checked, the options relative to this selection option are displayed.

  usebounds - When the Enable button is checked under the Bounding button, the selection options become active and can be used to select entities. The fields available are listed below. The bounding volume can be seen in the viewport as guide geometry.


		
  boundtype -  - Selects the type of bounding volume to use:

 usebbox - Bounding Box entities contained within the box are selected. usebsphere - Bounding Sphere entities contained within the sphere are selected.
		
  size -  - Dimensions of either the Bounding Box or Bounding Sphere in X, Y and Z.

 sizex - sizey - sizez -
		
  t -  - The X, Y, and Z coordinates of the center of the bounding volume.

 tx - ty - tz -



This option is used for selecting entities based on the angle of the entity normals. When checked, the options relative to this selection option are displayed.

  usenormal - When the Enable button is checked under the Normal button, the selection options become active and can be used to select entities. The fields available are listed below.	
The primary axis and the spread angle from the defined axis define a range of angles. If any entity normals lie within this range, then the associated entity is selected.			
For example; if you want to select the polygons that are very steep in a polygon mountain terrain on the XZ axis. You would set the Direction to be 0, 1, 0 and the spread angle to around 75. This selects all the polygons with normals that lie flat to fairly sloped. You will have grouped all of the polygons that lie flat up to polys that are at a 75 angle from the axis. You are left with all of the polygons that are 76 or greater.


		
  dir -  - The default values of 0, 1, 0 create a normal vector straight up in Y, which is perpendicular to the XZ plane, which becomes the primary axis. The 1, 0, 0 points the normal in positive X, giving a normal axis perpendicular to the YZ. The plane may be positioned at an angle by using values typed in (1, 1, 0 gives a 45 angle plane) or interactively by using the direction vector jack. Values between 0 and 1 should be used.

 dirx - diry - dirz -
		
  angle - The value entered in this field generates an angle of deviation from the primary axis. This can be visualized as a cone where the radius of the base of the cone is defined by the Spread Angle and the axis of the cone is determined by the Direction axis. Viewing the primitive normals in the viewport, you can see that any primitives with normals that have an angle that lies in the range of angles defined by the cone will be selected and grouped.


		
  camera - This menu allows you to select an object. Typically, a camera object would be chosen. The primitives which are backface when viewed from the object specified will be grouped or selected.




  removegrp - If any group has 0 entries and if this parameter is enabled, then those groups are removed. If you want to keep empty groups, disable this parameter.


			
  keeppoints - Deletes the geometry but keeps the points.


			

 -

Extra Information for the Delete  can be accessed via an Info CHOP.



 - Number of points in this . - Number of primitives in this . - Number of particles in this . - Time spent in another thread updating geometry data on the  from the 's CPU data. As it is part of another thread, this time is not part of the usual frame time. - Time spent in another thread updating meta surface geometry data (such as metaballs or nurbs) on the  from the 's CPU data. As it is part of another thread, this time is not part of the usual frame time.
 - Number of times the operator has cooked since the process started. - Duration of the last cook in milliseconds. - Frame number when this operator was last cooked relative to the component timeline. - Frame number when this operator was last cooked relative to the absolute time. - Time in milliseconds at which the operator started cooking in the frame it was cooked. - Time in milliseconds at which the operator finished cooking in the frame it was cooked. - 1 if operator was cooked this frame. - Number of warnings in this operator if any. - Number of errors in this operator if any.
TouchDesigner Build: Latest\n2022.241402021.100002018.28070before 2018.28070
SOPs
• • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • 

A Operator Family that reads, creates and modifies 3D points, polygons, lines, particles, surfaces, spheres and meatballs. Particles and point clouds are now done primarily on the GPU using TOPs.



The 3D data held in SOPs and passed for rendering by the Geometry COMP.



A polygon is a type of Primitive that is formed from a set of Vertices in 3D that are implicitly connected together to form a multi-edge shape.



A text string that contains data (string, float, list, boolean, etc.) and operators (+ * < etc) that are evaluated by the node's language (python or Tscript) and returns a string, float list or boolean, etc. Expressions are used in parameters, DATs and in scripts.



Matching names using wildcard characters and bracketing. Useful in "Select" type parameters to select multiple operators, paths, channels, etc.



An Operator Family which operate on Channels (a sequence of numbers (Samples)) which are used for animation, audio, mathematics, simulation, logic, UI construction, and data streamed from/to devices and protocols.



The Graphics Processing Unit. This is the high-speed, many-core processor of the graphics card/chip that takes geometry, images and data from the CPU and creates images and processed data.








Retrieved from "https://docs.derivative.ca/index.php?title=Delete_SOP&oldid=24259"
		Category: SOPs

Contents
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 





  group - The name of the group to be created. The default name is set to match the name of the .

  entity -  - Choose to delete primitives or points.

The required syntax is "S.P", where S is the index of the parent surface, and P the profile index on that surface. You can mix primitives with profiles in the list. A mixed group is automatically ordered.	
For example;0.4 2 4 2.5 3.7 selects three profiles and two primitives0-100:2 selects every other number from 0 to 1000-10:2,3 selects every two of three0.0-6 selects six profiles on primitive 00.* selects all profiles on primitive 0!4 selects every primitive or point except the fourth9-0 selects first ten (in reverse if ordered flag is on)!0.* selects all profiles except those on primitive 0* selects all primitives or points, and no profiles

For example; entering 1 and 2 selects 1 out of every 2 entities


select1 -select2 -

  t -  - The X, Y, and Z coordinates of the center of the bounding volume.

Viewing the primitive normals in the viewport, you can see that any primitives with normals that have an angle that lies in the range of angles defined by the cone will be selected and grouped.

 - Number of points in this . - Number of primitives in this . - Number of particles in this . - Time spent in another thread updating geometry data on the  from the 's CPU data. As it is part of another thread, this time is not part of the usual frame time. - Time spent in another thread updating meta surface geometry data (such as metaballs or nurbs) on the  from the 's CPU data. As it is part of another thread, this time is not part of the usual frame time.
 - Number of times the operator has cooked since the process started. - Duration of the last cook in milliseconds. - Frame number when this operator was last cooked relative to the component timeline. - Frame number when this operator was last cooked relative to the absolute time. - Time in milliseconds at which the operator started cooking in the frame it was cooked. - Time in milliseconds at which the operator finished cooking in the frame it was cooked. - 1 if operator was cooked this frame. - Number of warnings in this operator if any. - Number of errors in this operator if any.

parameters.label: Start / End
parameters.description:
range -  - Activated when Operation is set to Group by Range. Select the start and end of the primitive/point number selection.

rangestart -rangeend -

parameters.name: Select _ of _
parameters.label: Select _ of _
parameters.description:
select -  - Activated when Operation is set to Group by Range. Select every nth occurrence of every mth entity in the above Start/End range.	
For example; entering 1 and 2 selects 1 out of every 2 entities


select1 -select2 -

parameters.name: Filter Expression
parameters.label: Filter Expression
parameters.description: filter - The Filter  provided is evaluated for every point/primitive. Wherever it is true, the entity is added to the selection.

parameters.name: Use Bounds
parameters.label: Use Bounds
parameters.description: usebounds - When the Enable button is checked under the Bounding button, the selection options become active and can be used to select entities. The fields available are listed below. The bounding volume can be seen in the viewport as guide geometry.

parameters.name: Bounding Type
parameters.label: Bounding Type
parameters.description:
boundtype -  - Selects the type of bounding volume to use:

 usebbox - Bounding Box entities contained within the box are selected. usebsphere - Bounding Sphere entities contained within the sphere are selected.

parameters.name: Bounding Box
parameters.label: Bounding Box
parameters.description: usebbox - Bounding Box entities contained within the box are selected. usebsphere - Bounding Sphere entities contained within the sphere are selected.

parameters.name: Size
parameters.label: Size
parameters.description:
size -  - Dimensions of either the Bounding Box or Bounding Sphere in X, Y and Z.

 sizex - sizey - sizez -

parameters.name: X
parameters.label: X
parameters.description: sizex - sizey - sizez -

parameters.name: Center
parameters.label: Center
parameters.description:
t -  - The X, Y, and Z coordinates of the center of the bounding volume.

 tx - ty - tz -

parameters.name: X
parameters.label: X
parameters.description: tx - ty - tz -

parameters.name: Use Normal
parameters.label: Use Normal
parameters.description:
usenormal - When the Enable button is checked under the Normal button, the selection options become active and can be used to select entities. The fields available are listed below.	
The primary axis and the spread angle from the defined axis define a range of angles. If any entity normals lie within this range, then the associated entity is selected.			
For example; if you want to select the polygons that are very steep in a polygon mountain terrain on the XZ axis. You would set the Direction to be 0, 1, 0 and the spread angle to around 75. This selects all the polygons with normals that lie flat to fairly sloped. You will have grouped all of the polygons that lie flat up to polys that are at a 75 angle from the axis. You are left with all of the polygons that are 76 or greater.

parameters.name: Direction
parameters.label: Direction
parameters.description:
dir -  - The default values of 0, 1, 0 create a normal vector straight up in Y, which is perpendicular to the XZ plane, which becomes the primary axis. The 1, 0, 0 points the normal in positive X, giving a normal axis perpendicular to the YZ. The plane may be positioned at an angle by using values typed in (1, 1, 0 gives a 45 angle plane) or interactively by using the direction vector jack. Values between 0 and 1 should be used.

 dirx - diry - dirz -

parameters.name: X
parameters.label: X
parameters.description: dirx - diry - dirz -

parameters.name: Spread Angle
parameters.label: Spread Angle
parameters.description: angle - The value entered in this field generates an angle of deviation from the primary axis. This can be visualized as a cone where the radius of the base of the cone is defined by the Spread Angle and the axis of the cone is determined by the Direction axis. Viewing the primitive normals in the viewport, you can see that any primitives with normals that have an angle that lies in the range of angles defined by the cone will be selected and grouped.

parameters.name: Backface from
parameters.label: Backface from
parameters.description: camera - This menu allows you to select an object. Typically, a camera object would be chosen. The primitives which are backface when viewed from the object specified will be grouped or selected.

parameters.name: Delete Unused Groups
parameters.label: Delete Unused Groups
parameters.description: removegrp - If any group has 0 entries and if this parameter is enabled, then those groups are removed. If you want to keep empty groups, disable this parameter.

parameters.name: Delete Geometry, Keep Points
parameters.label: Delete Geometry, Keep Points
parameters.description: keeppoints - Deletes the geometry but keeps the points.
